rule_5.title: Quotations
rule_5.description: Complete extraction of Rule 5 (Quotations) from the Bluebook

sub_rules.title: Formatting of Quotations
sub_rules.text: Quotations of fifty or more words should be formatted as block quotations (indented and without quotation marks). Shorter quotations remain in-line with quotation marks. When using a block quotation, maintain the original formatting, including internal quotation marks. Use an ellipsis to indicate omitted material and brackets to indicate changes or additions.

block_quote_threshold.description: Quotations of 50+ words must be block quoted

sub_rules.title: Alterations and Quotations Within Quotations
sub_rules.text: Indicate any alteration to a quoted text with brackets, including added or changed letters or words. Use "[sic]" after an error in the original that is being preserved. When quoting text that itself contains a quotation, alternate between double and single quotation marks (with the outermost quotes determined by the context of your quote).

sic_usage.description: Indicates error or misspelling in original

sub_rules.title: Omissions
sub_rules.text: Use an ellipsis ("...") to indicate omitted material within a quotation. Do not begin a quote with an ellipsis if the quoted material starts midsentence; simply begin with a lowercase letter (bracketed if needed). Ensure the omission does not alter the fundamental meaning of the quoted text.

meaning_preservation.requirement: omission must not alter fundamental meaning

sub_rules.title: Placement of Punctuation Marks
sub_rules.text: When a punctuation mark is present in the underlying material but not intended to be part of the quotation, the punctuation mark should be omitted if it comes at the end of a quotation and should be included if it comes at the beginning of a quotation. See BB 5.1.

punctuation_at_end.condition: punctuation present in material but not part of quote

punctuation_at_beginning.condition: punctuation present in material but not part of quote

example_1.original: The court stated: 'Justice must be served.'

sub_rules.title: Block Quotes
sub_rules.text: SLR follows BB 5.1 in using block quotes for quotations of fifty or more words. As BB 5.1(a) suggests, it is often permissible to avoid a block quote by simply not quoting extraneous language (e.g., starting and ending a quote in the middle of a sentence), and you should do so when possible. But do not rewrite quotes just to avoid block quoting, and do not try to sneak in a forty-nine-word quotation to avoid a block quote when a longer quote would provide essential context.

restrictions.do_not_use_forty_nine_words: when longer quote provides essential context
restrictions.emphasis: integrity of quotation matters more than avoiding block quote

word_count_guidance.note: word count does not include citations within quotation

sub_rules.title: Omissions from Quotations
sub_rules.text: Use an ellipsis ( . . . ) to indicate the omission of one or more words from the middle of a quoted sentence. Do not use an ellipsis at the beginning of a quotation (even if the beginning of the sentence is omitted) or at the end of a quotation (even if the end of the sentence is omitted) unless what follows in the sentence is also omitted. If one or more full sentences are omitted from the quotation, use an ellipsis that includes end punctuation (e.g., ". . . ."). Leave a space before and after each period in the ellipsis. Do not omit punctuation before or after the ellipsis unless it is a comma that serves only to indicate a series of items. See BB 5.3–5.4.

ellipsis_format.spacing: space before and after each period

beginning.note: even if beginning of sentence omitted

end.exception: if what follows in sentence is also omitted

punctuation_handling.exception: comma serving only to indicate series of items

sub_rules.title: Alterations to Quotations
sub_rules.text: Use brackets to indicate any alterations to the text of a quotation, including altered capitalization, added or changed emphasis, or added footnote call numbers. See RB 1.13; BB 5.2. Use "[sic]" to indicate any obvious errors or misprints in the original quotation that you cannot correct (but for minor errors, consider paraphrasing instead). Do not use "[sic]" to indicate an alternate but still correct spelling (e.g., alternate spelling of a word ending in "-ize" or "-yze"). See RB 24.1.

emphasis.note: or use brackets with emphasis indicator

sub_rules.title: Textual Citations Within Quotations
sub_rules.text: In general, citations within quotations should be omitted unless particularly relevant. Original source: The Court specified "with all deliberate speed," Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity. Article: As one commentator noted, "The Court specified 'with all deliberate speed,' but that phrase is not a model of clarity."373 373. Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955)). If the quoted citation is particularly relevant and must be retained, it should appear as it does in the quoted source—including, unfortunately, any Bluebooking errors.

retention.include_errors: yes - preserve any Bluebooking errors from original

parenthetical_use.purpose: indicates citations were removed from quote

with_citation_in_original.original_text: The Court specified "with all deliberate speed," Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity.
with_citation_in_original.edited_text: As one commentator noted, "The Court specified 'with all deliberate speed,' but that phrase is not a model of clarity."
with_citation_in_original.footnote: Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955))

alteration_best_practices: Use [sic] sparingly - only for significant errors
omission_best_practices: Avoid ending quotation with ellipsis unless necessary
Preserve meaning - never distort with omissions
Use four-period ellipsis for complete sentence omissions
